Title: Conjecture $\int_0^1\frac{\ln\left(\ln^2x+\arccos^2x\right)}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}dx\stackrel?=\pi\,\ln\ln2$
Content:
$$\int_0^1\frac{\ln\left(\ln^2x+\arccos^2x\right)}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}dx\stackrel?=\pi\,\ln\ln2$$
Is it possible to prove this?
AcceptedAnswer: Substitute $x \mapsto \cos x$ to obtain an equivalent formulation: $$ \int_{0}^{\frac{\pi}{2}} \log(x^{2} + \log^{2}\cos x) \, dx = \pi \log \log 2. $$ You can find my solution here .
llm_answer_create_structured_problem:
###BEGIN_OF_FORMAT###
Assumption: 
The integration variable $x$ is within the interval $[0, 1]$,  
The integral is interpreted as an improper integral due to singularities at $x = 0$ and $x = 1$.  
Problem:  
Prove that  
$$\int_0^1\frac{\ln\left(\ln^2x+\arccos^2x\right)}{\sqrt{1-x^2}}dx=\pi\,\ln\ln 2.$$
###
